subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello
and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. We’ll
be exploring the subject of animals in
the afterlife. With me is Miranda Alcott.
She is an intuitive animal communicator.
She’s also the author of a chapter about
“Listening to Water” in the book The
Healing Power of Water edited by Masaru
Emoto. Welcome, Miranda. Thank you, Jeffrey.
It’s lovely to be here. It’s a pleasure to be with you, once again. I know you
have a lot to say about this subject,
meaning that you have had many experiences,
many intuitions, you’ve been with many animals
and their owners or their partners
during that transition. Many of our
viewers are probably justifiably
skeptical when we talk about the
afterlife, especially based on somebody's
intuitions and
I think that's fine. We'll just regard
your intuitive impressions as a source
of data. People can do with it as they
wish. Exactly. I'm only here to offer some
opportunities of different ways of
holding information and seeing how you
feel. Most people do have feelings from
their animals after they've transitioned,
after the animal has left its body.
Some people will hear toenails
on the ground. Other people will feel the
animal jump onto the bed. They want to
know, “What does it mean, and
is that animal really with me?” So,
there are those basic kinds of questions
that I guess, but then also it goes
into a deeper place, which is my favorite
place to work, which is what I call the
intersection, which is the intersection
of where those two beings still have to
learn from each other. In other words, the
relationship can continue. Absolutely.
Just as it might with a human. Yes.
Absolutely. When I was very young I worked with humans who had
transitioned and I stopped doing it for
a long time because I got tired of, “Where
did aunt Harriet bury the treasure?”
That was some kind of a seance or challenge...
That's not the type of
work that I do. The type of work that I
get to do, and so blessed, is what do we
have to learn from each other still? So,
sometimes there will be animals that
maybe were hit by a car
and the human is very upset because the
animal left its body, and it was very hard.
Sometimes the animal has been sick for a
very long time and the animal has to
transition. Other times the human, they
come and they say, “My animal is very sick
and I want to know if he's ready to transition and does he need help or does
he want to be left alone?” Well, there are
many issues that you're raising here.
There's the transition process,
there's the grieving process, and then
there's the whole metaphysical question
about the after life itself. Yeah. And I
see it as a continuum. I don't
see it as separate then, because also
many times after the animal has
transitioned, the human is still learning.
And there are still wonderful lessons to
be shared and things to be learned. I just feel I’m one
of the most fortunate people there is,
simply because I get to support people
in their healing and learning and
growing and the same with the animals.
They are all people to me. Well, you serve
as a medium of communication between a
deceased animal and a human. Right, right.
And then there are also times when
perhaps a human has taken their life
and their animal has witnessed it. So,
that's the reverse of what we normally
think. That actually happens more
times than we wish it would, obviously.
We wouldn’t like it to happen at all. But many times the
animal is shattered or has trauma
they're trying to get over it because they
witnessed it, because they tried to help
their human feel better. They tried to
express love in such a way that this
human wouldn't feel the need to do that,
or have to do that. But as it turns
out we can't control each other. All they
can do is offer and hopefully
provide some recourse. So after the
fact, we can connect again and see if
there's more learning and healing and
growing to be done. Also I know... I
wanted to mention that there does seem
to be a change that happens in whomever
has transitioned, whether it's human or
animal, where that being seems to have
softened some, not always, but sometimes. So
for instance, if an animal is
cantankerous or jealous or very
territorial, many times the human is
expecting that the animal will be the
same way. And I haven't found that to be
true. I found that the human knows if
they're connecting with their own animal,
usually there are tears. They know when they
hear something that resonates with them.
They know it's their animal. Well, how
does your intuition work in this regard?
If you're trying to tune in to a deceased
animal, how do you find that particular
animal and recognize it yourself? What a
great question. For me, I ask if they
have a picture of the animal. If they
don't, I'll ask them to describe the animal. As they are describing the
animal, I'm using their energetic
patterns to trace the energy to wherever that is.
I don't go out. I'm not trying to make it
sound as though I do. But I will know if
the energy that comes into a gathering
shows itself in some form that we have
that exact intersection. You're not a
trance medium. No. You're operating, I'm
going to say, at a telepathic level,
a conscious level and you're picking
up impressions and communicating.
Yes. That's right. I'm working from purely
an energetic standpoint. If the energy
patterning matches, the person will
let me know simply by their identifying and knowing they're hearing, from their
animal, what's being said. So, I presume if
a human were to transition, you would be
able to pick up on them as well. Yes. I used to do that a lot when I
was a child but I got to a place where I
was tired of people asking, “Where did aunt
Harriet bury the treasure.” And that's because really the work that I
get to do is really focused and based on
healing and involvement. And here's what
I mean by that. We all have lessons we’re
working on. We don't usually complete
everything in one lifetime. So do the
animals. If their spirit
happens to be in an animal body, then
that's what they are learning at that
time. But to connect both the animal and
the human at the exact intersection of
where they still have to learn from each
other is where I work. And it's very
exciting. You could do that with two humans
also, couldn't you? Yes. And that actually
has happened because I do work with
people who've taken their lives and
their animals maybe have
witnessed, or just the person
themselves. In my experience, I'm not
an animal person, I like animals, but I
don't have any in my life. In any case,
I have observed that when a pet or animal
companion dies, people experience as much
grief as if it were a family member. Or
if not more. I can't tell you how many
people I have heard say to me, “This is
harder than when I lost my mother,” or, “This is harder than when I lost my
brother,” which is not to berate or
lessen the human. It's that that being,
they have offered them unconditional love
for so long, that was a part of their
everyday of how they process, how they
live, the human. And so, to not have
that in their perception, to not have that, can
be very challenging. That's one thing
the animals taught me many years ago.
They asked me, “Why is it when we leave
our bodies that the humans disconnect
from us, why do they say because they
can't see us we're not here, why do they do that?”
And it’s an interesting,
challenging position to be in, to explain
how that can happen to someone.
Usually by the time I get them
relaxed, then they are willing to be
receiving of that information that comes
through for them. I see. Well, let's talk a
little also about the afterlife itself.
I have a hard time conceptualizing it
because it seems as if it's a place, like
it has a location somewhere. You know,
it's interesting. It depends on the
person's belief system, because everyone
wants to know that their horse has
endless amounts of grains that they love,
alfalfa, or whatever their sweet
treat is, Timothy pellets or whatever.
With many dogs, people want to
see that their dogs are just running on grass and having every kind of ball they
want. It depends on how the human is
holding what their idea is. I have not
found it to be a place. I've found it to be
a frequency, a very different
energetic. But it isn’t up to me. My job
is to hold whatever those two need to
have for them, to support them to know
they have not disappeared.
That's another thing that animals say to
me, “Please tell my human, stop referring
to me in the past. If I were in the past,
how could we communicate? Why does she say,
he used to be so?” And the human will
say, “You mean I can still communicate?” I'm saying yes, especially
just before you fall asleep. If you say,
“I'm only open to that which is for my
highest good,” and so that Spot, or
my animal will come through.
I'm willing to travel with that animal
for a few minutes before I go to sleep.
So, they're now programming and
requesting with wonderful elements
inside of “only for my highest good” to go
on this journey themselves, without using
me. Well, the spiritualist literature,
which I've delved into a bit, suggests
that at least in the early stages of
being in the afterlife state, we populate
it with our own thought forms. Yes.
Absolutely.
And eventually, we may evolve beyond the need
to do that and enter into a different
realm entirely, but there's at least a
transitory period where we experience
the world around us as we think it to be.
Yes. Exactly, which is why one of
the things that I really enjoy is when
an animal is about to transition and we
know there's going to be euthanasia.
There are children in the family, the
parents are usually panicking, “Oh my gosh,
what do we do with the kids?” One of my
favorite things is to suggest that the
children draw pictures or write letters
to send with the animal so that the
animal can take them. That’s a wonderful way to work with that. And in
fact, those children grow up to be adults
who believe that their letters went with
them, or they can visualize and see
that that was part of the step of
getting to an afterlife. Children are
much more open about this. Well, I also
gather from the afterlife literature,
which is actually quite vast, that
communication doesn't last forever.
Sooner or later, whoever it is is going
to move into a realm where communicating
with the earthly plane is just no longer
important. Right. And either they have new
assignments that they take on or receive
or they go back into just a pure
energetic state, meaning they can join anywhere
and they don't necessarily stay in a
confirmation of being an animal or a
human or that personality. But very
much of that soul continuing on.
That’s been my experience, is that there is only a
certain amount of time. A window. Yeah,
there's a window, but it can be
very long for some people. It could be for years. It can be,
because if those two beings still have
more to do together, there are many
people that teach without
themselves realizing it, when they turn
and talk to a coworker, they
can still feel their animals. Their
animal’s right alongside them and they
tell stories about it and then they say, “I know that I was getting a coffee this
morning and I could hear his toenails on
the floor and I just turned around and of course he wasn't there but I could
hear him.” Now, they're teaching when they
share that experience. And those animals
go right alongside with their humans
for a while and they teach together or
they grow together. There are many
animals who express incredibly
articulate guidance to their humans
from the afterlife about what they need
to work on in their lives. And the human
could not hear it before. I’ve worked with
people where their animals have told them that before they left and they
didn't comprehend it. They didn't take it
in at a level. And then they come and
they want to hear what their animal says
and then they’ll hear it, because now they're
much more vulnerable. They're willing to
listen. They're willing to be open.
They're willing to give it a chance. Well,
what we're touching on is a topic from a
previous interview about things that
animals have to teach us. And that's
really quite extensive. What you're
saying is it goes on even after the
transition. Animals can be teachers
from the other side.
Another point you raised in an earlier
interview, maybe we can come back to, is
the idea of spirit guides and animals
can work with spirit guides. They have
spirit guides. Well, animals can become
someone's spirit guide, but animals have
their own teachers, yes.
I don't know that I would
call them spirit guides, but they’re forms
of teachers, just as if that's what the
human wants to call them. The human can
call them angels, spirit guides, master
teachers. Everyone has their own focus of
how they want to... A Jungian might call them
an archetype. There we are. Yeah. So, I haven't found it to be any
one way. It's very multiverse. Well, would
you say that animals and humans can be
together in an afterlife? Usually in
the beginning of the transition many people
picture that. They develop that that's what they want and that's what
happens. I know many people when their animal has
transitioned want to know that a
relative welcomed their animal. Are they
together? Can it happen? And yes, it can
happen. As a matter of fact, there are
teams that meet up on the other side,
which is kind of fun to witness and watch.
Explain that. For instance, there was a family I
worked with that had a couple of animals
that transitioned, and then suddenly
the wife became very ill and she knew she
was going to be transitioning, and she
wanted to know if anyone was going to be
waiting for her. In fact, the dogs
were there waiting with a catcher's mitt.
She felt so relieved that it was a
really wonderful easy transition, knowing
that she was going to something. I think
that's a great factor in all of it. And you were
there.
And she's talking to you about what happens? Oh no, she's
talking and her family told me that she
was seeing them as she was transitioning.
And she was saying, “They're here. Skippy is
here,” and, “Ah, look at Goo, Goo is
here too.” And she was so excited and lit
up. But if you are there
in this circumstance, you might see what
she's also seeing. Yes, as a matter of
fact, I've seen that with humans as well.
There was one gentleman in particular who
had, as he was transitioning, he
sat up and he was seeing things. I
asked what he was seeing and he [said], “Oh, oh!”
I couldn't imagine what, so I asked
to see what he was seeing. And it
looked like a Fellini movie to me. It was
in black and white with very extreme…
And I said to this gentleman, “It's like a
Fellini movie.” And he said, “How did you
know?” And it turned out he was a film buff,
and that surprised me. Yeah. I
could imagine the afterlife as a Fellini film, as a matter of fact.
I could really get into that. There you go. Well then,
Jeffrey, we’ll make sure. Well, now what
about other wild animals? About wild animals...
Yeah, like do they have an afterlife?
Have you had any experience of
that? I have actually. I've seen wild
animals come back around and hold for
the rest of their pack or their pride,
which is a fascinating experience
because when animals are sickly,
there are certain cultures, certain
species that will take down their own
kind, because an animal that is sick in
that pack is actually lowering the
energetic of the rest of the pack. But
what's fascinating is after that being
transitions, what energy
they have now renews and they put it
back into the pack and they can oversee
it as well. So there are pack leaders,
in other words, in the animal kingdom,
that will use one of their wise animals,
as we might say, as a north star.
And that happens for a while and
again everyone goes on and moves on,
either into a pure energetic or
dissipates into energy. And
I would assume, that reincarnation of
animals is also something you might
experience. Yes. And I get a lot of questions about that. There are people
that come that want their animals to
come back in. Then there
are people that come and say, “You're not
gonna believe this, but I swear this
is an animal I had when I was growing up.”
And we ask whether it is or not.
Sometimes it is and sometimes it's
another animal that that animal has sent
to take care of that human. I know
there's a popular film out right now
about a dog that incarnates five or
six successive times. So, it's a theme
picked up by Hollywood. A Dog’s Life. Yeah.
But what you're saying is that in your
very authentic intuitive experience, I
call it very authentic and let me just
say why briefly and that is, based on a
concept developed by the great
psychologist and philosopher William
James called radical empiricism, that the
most direct observations of the world
that we get come from our intuitions,
from our observations of our own consciousness.
That's real data, just as much to me
as if you were reading the dials on
a scientific instrument.
I appreciate your sharing that, because
for me it is always real. It has been
real and it was quite an adjustment
coming into this life.
I couldn't believe people didn't know
where they have just been and I couldn't
believe that they wouldn't speak to the animals in their lives.
Why would you draw a line? Why
would you do that? And in fact, some of
the people that are in human experience
right now, that are most challenged about
being alive right now, at this time on
the planet, are very sensitive beings who
have not shut down the right side of
their brain. This is a very challenging
time to be that sensitive, here. Yeah,
many people are called
empaths, for example. And I know
because we are in a culture that doesn't
support it. Our culture is off
balance. It is off balance. Thank you for
saying that. It is off balance
and I encourage, as I have many students
that come into the classes that haven't
been given credit for being empathic or
they're ashamed of it or they're
embarrassed about it. And it's taken me
years to figure out how to deal with that because I came in excited about all
there was and then had to pull
it back in because other people weren’t.
One of my favorite
teaching stories was I was so used to
hearing people say, “Well, you're just so
sensitive.” In fact, my mother would
even say, “Well, honey, you're so unique.” And
it was really hard to be on the
receiving end of it, because where I came
from, that was a good thing and to have
this in this lifetime have it be
something bad. So what I share
with my students is, just not too long
ago, I was having some dental work done
and the dentist was complaining about
the novocaine and how much she had to
give me. She said, “Miranda, you are just
so sensitive.” And I said, “Yes, and that's
how I make my living.” Well, indeed you do.
The truth is, as you’ve explained to
me in the past, your parents are probably
much more supportive than most. They were
board members of the American Society
for Psychical Research. They were
knowledgeable about this arena. They were,
but even they said, “That's fine, honey,
just keep it in the house.” Which is
sometimes good advice. Yes it is,
especially when you're growing up. Especially when you’re growing up
because you don't know that people can't
see other people or that they can't see
other forms of energy. Well, one of the
purposes of these videos, of this
video channel, is to offer a certain
amount of validation for people who
might be the way you were as a child. And
I really appreciate the work that you do,
Jeffrey, because you expose all of us to things that we would not have been
exposed to. And it is so important for
people to know it's okay to be who they
are and to prize their sensitivities
instead of trying to hide them or shove
them down. So thank you for the work that you do.
Well, you know, it takes a certain
amount of courage on your part to come and
create a video which will be shown all
over the world talking about animals and
the afterlife. I'm excited about it. It's
time. It’s time. Yeah, I can tell
from the way you're speaking, you really
don't have any doubt about your perceptions. No. You’re not questioning
this reality at all, are you? No. You
know, I have limitations.
Those aren’t some of them. So I
don't have the limit of that. I have
other ones. We all come in with things to work on.
But doubting yourself isn’t one. Not
in this area. I have had too many things
working with people that transitioned or
victims of violent crime,
certainly my experience on Ground Zero. Yes, you’ve done a lot of rescue work.
And you have to prepare for that on so
many levels, especially being sensitive.
So yeah. I've had a lot of
experience, I'm happy to say. And then
also tough things about, how do you deal
with that when you're in a
crisis? How do you do that being empathic
and not get involved in that energetic?
That's really tough. Because I think for
myself, speaking for myself, it's easier
to close down then to have to feel other
people's pain. And there's also something
very primal that when a person is scream-
crying, it actually resonates inside of
us on a vibrational level, fear to the
core. So it is something that we have to train for and something we have to be
cognizant of and something we have to
monitor. Well, Miranda Alcott, I know we've
just scratched the surface of a vast
topic. We could talk forever. Which I
would enjoy, because I enjoy listening to you
and speaking with you. Thank you, and I know
for anyone who's willing to put up with
it, we've got already 100
hours of video on the internet and there
will be more to come. But for now,
Miranda, this has been wonderful. Thank
you so much for being with me. Thank you
for inviting me, Jeffrey. My pleasure. And
thank you for being with us.
[Music]
